Name: Sixth Bureau
Comments: articles 16-18

Name: Bonnal
Comments: articles 16-17

Name: Laborde
Comments: pro-toleration

Name: Mirabeau (comte)
Comments: toleration too weak; absolute right!

Name: Eymar
Comments: pro-established religion (on Anglican model)

Name: Petion de Villeneuve
Comments: rejecting arts 16-17

Name: Castellane
Comments: first half conservative ("La religion étant le plus solide de tous les biens politiques"), second half liberal/libertarian ("nul homme ne peut être inquiété dans ses opinions religieuses")

Name: Bouche
Comments: rejecting arts 16-17

Name: Bouche
Comments: refs 1785 royal decree tolerating Protestantism

Name: Eymar
Comments: We'll leave discussion of 'culte' until the constitution. Focus on 'religion' for good order of society.

Name: Mirabeau (comte)
Comments: procedural point, opposing Eymar because the motion is to postpone debate over arts. 16-17

Name: Mirabeau (vicomte)
Comments: only "first part" ("Nul homme ne doit être inquiété pour ses opinions religieuses"); rejected second part, "ni troublé dans l'exercice de son culte"

Name: Clermont-Lodève
Comments: in favor of arts 16-17; cites Rousseau!

Name: Talleyrand
Comments: 17 belongs in the constitution and 16 is problematic.

Name: Castellane
Comments: Renews his motion: ""Nul homme ne doit être inquiété pour ses opinions religieuses ni troublé dans l'exercice de son culte"

Name: Mirabeau (comte)
Comments: attacks the second part of Castellane's motion (on the free exercise of religious culte)

Name: Castellane
Comments: defends his whole proposal

Name: Juigné
Comments: Opposes the motion to remove the second part.

Name: Rabaud de Saint-Etienne
Comments: Rabaud speaks at length and offers a proposal in favor of religious freedom. Essentially a plea for non catholics, i.e. protestants. "Tout homme est libre dans ses opinions; tout citoyen a le droit de professer librement son culte, et nul ne peut être inquiété à cause de sa religion."

Name: Gobel
Comments: no institutionalized status of religion/just about ordre public. No one can prevent non-catholics from practicing their religion. They must do so in a way that does not disturb public order. "...pourvu que leur manifestation ne troublé pas l'ordre public."

Name: anonymous
Comments: as established by the law is added to Gobel's ammendment.
